body: Update by trade code (code LOAD_BY_TRADE_CODE) - identify the security by using "Trade code".

title: Which "update code" is used to identify securities (pr.mode)
body: When importing security prices programmatically, you can use code pr.mode with the above LOAD_BY codes to determine which logic to use to identify your securities with the code you provide in pr.updateCode (available from FA 3.7 onward).

title: Which "close" the close prices are imported to (pr.n)
body: When importing security prices through the update menu, first row of the market price file can define (code pr.n), which "close" the prices are imported to. Security can have manual and up to five different close prices, and you can import prices to "manual" and any of the "closes". In the first row of the file, a numeric value 0 indicates the market price entries within the file are imported to the "manual" field (available from FA 2.4 onward), and a numeric value 1 through 5 indicates which "close" the market price entries within the file are imported to. If no numeric value is defined, the prices are imported to "Close 1". When using the update codes to import your prices (selection "Default" in the Import window), then the numeric value on the first row of the file also indicates which "Update code" is used to identify the securities: a numeric value 1 through 3 uses the corresponding "Update code" to identify the security, and imports the prices to the corresponding close.

title: Which "close" the close prices are imported to (pr.n)
body: When importing security prices through auto import in the update menu, a numeric value other than number 1 through 5 in the first row indicates that prices are updated with security's ISIN code and are saved to Close 1 (only available in Auto import).

title: Which "close" the close prices are imported to (pr.n)
body: When importing security prices programmatically, you can use codes pr.n (for the entire import) or or.updateColumn (for each row, available from FA 3.7 onward) with a numeric value 0 (manual), 1, 2, 3, 4 or 5 to indicate which "close" field you want to store pr.close into.

title: File format for importing account thresholds
body: Account thresholds are an optional feature that allows you to set the interest rate at different levels based on account balance. In FA Back, you can set up account thresholds in the Accounts tab of the Portfolio window. Read more about thresholds in Accounts.

title: File format for importing account thresholds
body: Thresholds are imported in FA in colon-separated text files (CSV) with the columns described below. One row in the file represents one threshold. The threshold import file is based on the column headers you define in the first row of the import file. You can specify the columns in any order and the system recognizes the values based on the header row text.

title: File format for importing account thresholds
body: Download the CSV file template here:

title: File format for importing account thresholds
body: FAFormat_thresholds.csv

title: File format for importing account thresholds
body: The file format is described below.

title: Delete account thresholds
body: You can only delete all thresholds at once for a given date. To delete an account threshold for a date, use ait.from="DELETE" in the import data for the date in question.

title: Modify account thresholds
body: You can only add or remove existing account thresholds with the importer. If you want to modify the thresholds for a specific date, delete the existing thresholds for that date and then add new ones.

title: Auto import
body: Auto import allows you to import contacts, portfolios, securities, market prices, transactions or trade orders to FA with an FA Format file.

title: Auto import
body: Files can be imported automatically through the following steps through Import - Auto import:

title: Auto import
body: Upload the file you want to import to the system with the Upload button. The uploaded file appears on the "Files" section on the left.

title: Auto import
body: Once you have uploaded all the files you want to import, you can can either import the files to FA immediately with the Import now button OR you can schedule the uploaded files to be imported later by defining the time and date of the import and clicking Schedule.

title: Auto import
body: After the files have been imported, one or more files are created to the "Imported" files section on the right. These files list separately the successful and failed imports.

title: Auto import
body: In addition to allowing you to schedule your imports for example night time, the auto import function facilitates manual importing: auto import allows you to process multiple FA Format files at once, and you don't need to import each file separately.

title: Format instructions
body: In order for the automatic import to work, the files have the follow the FA Format (see file formats for contacts and portfolios, securities and security prices, and transactions and trade orders), and the files have to be named in the following way:

title: Format instructions
body: securities.csv - security file

title: Format instructions
body: transactions.csv - transaction file

title: Format instructions
body: marketprices.csv - market price file

title: Format instructions
body: contacts.csv - contact file

title: Format instructions
body: portfolios.csv - portfolio file

title: Format instructions
body: thresholds.csv - account thresholds file

title: Format instructions
body: If there are multiple files of the same type within the imported files (for example if you have defined your market prices in different files), the files can be numbered in a form filename-x.csv (for example marketprices-2.csv).

title: Format instructions
body: You can also upload files as a zip package: you can save multiple files in the same folder and compress it into a zip package. The system automatically decompresses the zip package when it is uploaded to the system, and each individual file saved in the zip package appears in the "Files" section on the screen.

title: Uploading files
body: Automatic import is started by uploading the files to be imported to the server. The Upload button at the upper-left hand corner of the automatic import window opens up a menu, from which the automatically imported file is chosen. Files uploaded to the server can be seen in the Files listing on the left.

title: Uploading files
body: Files: x

title: Uploading files
body: Files: x - the files uploaded to the server are listed on the left with the name of the file. The heading of the also shows the number of files uploaded to the server (for example, Files: 1 indicates, that one file has been uploaded). The listing shows all the files uploaded with the Upload button, and you can perform functions to the files with a right-click of your mouse

title: Uploading files
body: Open - downloads the chosen CSV file to your computer, when you can view and modify it

title: Uploading files
body: Delete - deletes the chosen file from the server and the uploaded listing

title: Uploading files
body: Uploading files to the server does not yet import their content to the system. After uploading the files, you can choose to either import the files now with the appropriate button OR to schedule the uploaded files to be imported at an appropriate time.

title: Uploading files
body: Below the listing, there are three buttons visible:

title: Uploading files
body: Import now

title: Uploading files
body: Imports the uploaded files and saves all found securities, transactions, market prices, contacts and portfolios (based on the type of the files imported). The import function also reports any errors found in the file import.

title: Uploading files
body: Download not processed

title: Uploading files
body: Downloads the CSV files to your computer, when you can view and modify them.

title: Uploading files
body: Delete not processed

title: Uploading files
body: Deletes all, not processed file uploaded to the server.

title: Imported files
body: After pressing the Import now button - or after the scheduled import has gone through - the imported files together with the error files are listed in the window, in the listing visible.

title: Imported files
body: Imported files: x, Error files: x

title: Imported files
body: The files imported to the system can be seen on the right, listed with the name of the file and the status of the import. The heading of the listing shows the number of imported files and the number of error files (for example, Imported files: 1, Error files: 1 indicates, that one file has been imported correctly, and one file containing all the errors has been created). The listing shows all the files imported, which were uploaded to the server and processed either with the Import now button or with the scheduled automatic import. You can perform functions to the files with a right-click of your mouse:

title: Imported files
body: Open - downloads the chosen CSV file to your computer, when you can view and modify it.

title: Imported files
body: Delete - deletes the chosen file from the imported listing.

title: Imported files
body: The processed files are named according to successful imports and errors in importing the files.

title: Imported files
body: When importing FA Format files, each row in the import or error files represents one object imported (one new transaction, one new market price, one new security etc.): these rows are divided into imports and errors, each to their own file. The files are named in the following way:

title: Imported files
body: Successful imports: filename-imported-yyyymmddxxxxxx.csv (for example marketprices-imported-20111101111220.csv) includes the successfully imported lines from the original CSV file.

title: Imported files
body: Error files: filename-errors-yyyymmddxxxxxx.csv (for example marketprices-errors-20111101111220.csv) includes the lines with errors during the import from the original CSV file

title: Imported files
body: Below the listing, there are three buttons:

title: Imported files
body: Download all

title: Imported files
body: Downloads the processed files to your computer for you to view.

title: Imported files
body: Download errors

title: Imported files
body: Downloads all the error files to your computer for you to view.

title: Imported files
body: Delete all

title: Imported files
body: Deletes all processed files, both imported and error files.

title: Scheduled auto import
body: The Scheduled automatic import is defined in the field at the bottom of the window. Automatic processing can be scheduled on files uploaded to the server with the Upload button at the upper-left corner of the window, and are visible in the Files listing.

title: Scheduled auto import
body: There are two field visible:

title: Scheduled auto import
body: Time

title: Scheduled auto import
body: Define the time of the scheduled automatic import to the first field in a form hh:mm, for example 01:00. If only the time is defined without the date, the scheduled automatic import is starts every day at the defined time.

title: Scheduled auto import
body: Date

title: Scheduled auto import
body: Choose the date of the scheduled automatic import to the second field. If only the date is defined without the time, the scheduled automatic import starts as the day changes at 00:00.

title: Scheduled auto import
body: The Schedule button next to the fields saves the set time to be the start time of the automatic import - the files uploaded to the server will start to be processed at the set time.

title: TWR calculation
body: Analytics+ calculates performance using the time-weighted return (TWR) approach - this article describes the TWR calculation logic in Analytics+.

title: Time-weighted return (TWR) calculation logic
body: Time-weighted return (TWR) calculation logic main features:

title: Time-weighted return (TWR) calculation logic
body: The return is calculated based on daily profits and losses.

title: Time-weighted return (TWR) calculation logic
body: The TWR can be either market value- or exposure-based. The choice can be made on security type level (for more information about the TWR settings, see the Preference - Securities section). By default, futures are exposure-based and other security types are market value-based.

title: Time-weighted return (TWR) calculation logic
body: Supports both long and short position.

title: Market value (base)
body: Market value (base) is an optional base value that the daily profit and losses are compared against to get the daily return. The market value (base) is the market value in the morning (at the end of the previous day) adjusted by net cashflows during the date.

title: Market value (base)
body: The adjustment logic can be different depending on the option you chose in Preferences → Administration → Performance calculation (for details, see Preference - Administration). By default, the cashflows affect the market value (base) as follows:

title: Market value (base)
body: If the start market value of the day is zero (i.e. position does not exist in the morning):

title: Market value (base)
body: If there is positive net cash-flow (no negative net cash-flow) during the day, the positive net cash-flow is added to the market value (base).

title: Market value (base)
body: If there is negative net cash-flow (no positive net cash-flow) during the day, the negative net cash-flow pushes the market value (base) to be negative.

title: Market value (base)
body: If the start market value of the day is positive (i.e. there is a long position in the morning),

title: Market value (base)
body: Any positive net cash flow during the day is added to the market value (base).

title: Market value (base)
body: Any negative net cash-flow during the day is automatically included in the end of the day’s market value and therefore considered in the market value (base) for the next day.

title: Market value (base)
body: If the start market value of the day is negative (i.e. there is a short position in the morning), any negative net cashflow during the day is pushing the market value (base) further to the negative.

title: Market value (base)
body: On top and portfolio levels, portfolio level net cashflows are used instead of position level (internal) net cashflows.

title: Absolute exposure (base)
body: Absolute exposure (base) is an optional base value, that the daily profit and losses are compared against to get the daily return. The absolute exposure (base) is exposure in the morning (at the end of the previous day) adjusted by positive or negative exposure changes during the date.

title: Absolute exposure (base)
body: The adjustment logic can be different depending on the option you chose in Preferences → Administration → Performance calculation (for details, see Preference - Administration). By default, the cashflows affect the absolute exposure (base) as follows:

title: Absolute exposure (base)
body: If the start exposure of the day is zero (i.e. position does not exist in the morning):

title: Absolute exposure (base)
body: If there is positive change in exposure during the day, the positive exposure is added to the exposure (base).

title: Absolute exposure (base)
body: If there is negative change in exposure during the day, the negative change in exposure pushes the exposure (base) to be negative.

title: Absolute exposure (base)
body: If the start exposure of the day is positive (i.e. there is a long position in the morning), any positive change in exposure during the day is added to the exposure (base)

title: Absolute exposure (base)
body: If the start exposure of the day is negative (i.e. there is a short position in the morning), any negative change in exposure during the day is pushing to the exposure (base) further negative

title: Absolute exposure (base)
body: Absolute exposure (base) is then absolute (i.e. non-negative) exposure (base).

title: Carried cost - effect of costs and profits on cash positions
body: FA treats positions from cash accounts by default differently from others - the cost and profit transactions on cash accounts do not affect the cash positions TWR, but instead, the costs and profits are carried to the portfolio level and affects the TWR on that level. The reason for this is, that e.g. management fees are linked to an account but does not make sense on the account level TWR. It is also possible to remove this logic (controlled under security type Cash) and/or apply it to other security types in Preferences - Securities - Security types.

title: TWR contribution calculation logic
body: TWR Contribution is, simply put, the contribution a position (or group) has to the overall TWR this specific position (or group) is part of. The sum of all individual TWR contributions, should sum to the total TWR of the aggregate (for example a portfolio).

title: TWR contribution calculation logic
body: TWR Contribution is defined as the contribution a single constituent (e.g. position) has to the total group of constituents (e.g. portfolio). Interpreted as how much a single factor is contributing to a total, and can as such be done on any level or breakdown. E.g. positions can contribute to the total TWR of sector groups, which in turn can contribute to the total portfolio TWR, when split up into such parts. Also known as absolute return attribution. Contribution itself is not done against a benchmark.

title: TWR contribution calculation logic

title: Preference - Administration
body: Administration preferences include relevant preferences for system administrators.

title: Banner
body: In Banner preferences, you can define HTML to be displayed into the red toolbar. This allows you to utilize the space in the red toolbar more extensively, and to for example easily distinguish your test and production environments with a descriptive text.

title: Banner
body:
For example, HTML

TEST ENVIRONMENT

allows you to enter a noticeable text centered in the red banner.

title: Document management
body: Document management preferences allow you to adjust how your users can upload documents into the system (available from FA 3.5 onward).

title: Document management
body: Define maximum size for all uploaded files in megabytes (MB)

title: Document management
body: Allows you to define a maximum file size for documents your user can upload to the system. By default, there is no maximum file size.

title: Document management
body: Limit the frequency of document uploads

title: Document management
body: Allows you to define how many documents a user can upload, and how frequently rights to upload new documents will be available (e.g. a user can receive 1 new document to upload every 10 seconds). You can control the upload frequency with three settings:

title: Document management
body: Number of documents user can upload – The number of documents user can upload without any limit on upload frequency. By default, the number of documents is set to 1000.

title: Document management
body: Number of new documents to upload user receives at once – The number of new documents upload "rights" the user receives at the defined interval. By default, the number of new documents is set to 1000.

title: Document management
body: How often (seconds) user receives the new documents to upload – The freguency: how often the user gets the new document upload "rights". By default, the number of time is set to 1 second.

title: Document management
body: With the default configurations, users can upload 1000 documents without any limit, and get 1000 new documents to upload every second - in practice, this means that there is by default no limit on document upload frequency, unless the user tries to upload more than 1000 documents a second.

title: Document management
body: Adjusting the preferences above allows you to limit file uploads. If a user tries to upload files more frequently than allowed, the upload is prevented with a notification.

title: Document management
body: For example, set the number of documents to 5, new documents to 1, and time to 10 seconds. With this configuration, your users are able to upload 5 documents without a limit and will receive 1 new document to upload every 10 seconds. Every time your user uploads a document, the number of "uploads left" is reduced from five - after one upload, you have four uploads left, etc. The number of documents gets restored with one new document every ten seconds - if the user uploaded one document, reducing the "number of uploads left" to four, after ten seconds, the user would again have rights for full five uploads. If the user uploads more than five documents simultaneously or right after each other within ten seconds, further uploads are prevented until the user gets a "refill" of new documents to upload.

title: Email settings
body: Email settings contain fields for defining the settings for sending the emails (defined by FA when email reporting is enabled).

title: General
body: You can set the following general preferences:

title: General
body: Document management

title: General
body: Enable or disable document management. If enabled, documents can be attached to contacts, portfolios, transactions, and securities in the corresponding windows.

title: General
body: Language

title: General
body: Set the default language of the application to be either Suomi, English, or Svenska. The language setting defines the default language of the application: the user interface is shown with the selected language by default. The user can change the language of the user interface from Action - Languages (the language selection specific to the user name).

title: General
body: Enter button functionality

title: General
body: Define, how the Enter key behaves in the windows of FA Portfolio. There are three options available - the last of these options is selected by default:

title: General
body: "Enter navigates to the next field" – Set the Enter key to behave as the tabulator, navigating to the next field when pressed. Selected by default.

title: General
body: "Enter submits the form" – Set the Enter key to submit the open form when pressed (Enter acts as the Save / OK buttons).

title: General
body: "Enter does not do anything" – The Enter key does not have any extra functions.

title: Market data connection
body: The market data connection preferences are visible only if the functionality to import market data from an external source is enabled. Define the market data information to the field:

title: Market data connection
body: Earliest date of observation

title: Market data connection
body: Set the earliest date of the market data observations imported. External market price sources often have a long history of market price observations available, and it might not be worthwhile to save the entire market data history to FA. This field allows you to define the earliest date of market data observations.

title: Market data connection
body: Number of days market prices are fetched for in the nightly run

title: Market data connection
body: Define how many day's market data observations are fetched for and saved as market prices during the nightly run. The nightly run automatically fetches market prices for "Active" securities, for which a corresponding update code is defined. The default number of days to fetch during the nightly run is 5: this means that every night the prices from the previous 5 days are fetched and saved for securities as market prices.

title: Performance calculation
body: Performance calculation preferences define how net cash flows or net exposure affect the base for the daily TWR formula. The options are explained in the table.

title: Permissions
body: Permission preferences allow you to define and adjust permissions of each user role, i.e. adjust the rights to use the system per user role. The permissions are used to what users can access, view and edit when using FA.

title: Restrict reports to roles
body: Restricting reports to roles allows you to define which user roles have access to certain reports. Enter one or several semicolon-separated roles next to the report and click Save. If you leave the field empty, all users can generate the report in the Report window.

title: Restrict reports to roles
body: If a report is included in the report package, the user can generate only those reports in the package they have access to. The user gets a warning that some reports included in the package are unavailable. To learn more about the report packages, see the Report packages section.

title: Session timeout
body: Session timeout preferences allow you to control the application life cycle through "session timeout" and "heartbeat interval". These parameters are applied when a user is inactive, but the application is open and stays idle. (Available from FA 3.5 onward)

title: Session timeout
body: Heartbeat interval (minutes)

title: Session timeout
body: The default is 5 minutes. Heartbeat interval controls how often heartbeats that keep the user's session alive are sent. "UI instances are cleaned up if no communication is received from them after some time. If no other server requests are made, the client side sends keep-alive heartbeat requests. A UI is kept alive for as long as requests, or heartbeats, are received from it.”

title: Session timeout
body: Session timeout (minutes)

title: Session timeout
body: Default 30 minutes. Session timeout defines the time period for which the application remains “alive” without user interaction. Timeout is reset if the user performs some action within the application.

title: Session timeout
body: Manipulating session length by adjusting these two parameters in FA Back and the corresponding KeyCloak setting means that the application can function in two ways:

title: Session timeout
body: If the heartbeat is set to be longer than the session timeout, the session will always die after the timeout.

title: Session timeout
body: If the heartbeat interval is shorter than the session, the session will never expire.

title: Update report
body: Update report preferences allow you to define how and when portfolio report data is updated.

title: Update report
body: Disable report updates

title: Update report
body: Disables all report updates. Use this option to speed up data import when importing large volumes of data. After the import is completed, you should:

title: Update report
body: Recalculate the report data. Click Update in the top menu and choose Recalculate all report data of all portfolios.

title: Update report
body: Re-run posting rules if they are used. Click the Generate postings at the bottom of the Transactions view.

title: Update report
body: Update reports immediately

title: Update report
body: Enables report update after changes. When enabled, portfolios' reports are updated after every change made that affects the reports. When disabled, the reports have to be updated manually or automatic update can update the portfolio reports at night.

title: Update report
body: Automatically update reports

title: Update report
body: Enables or disables automatic nightly report data update. If you are using a market data connector, the nightly report data update first fetches the latest market price entries through your market data connector and then recalculates report data with the latest close prices.

title: Update report
body: Update time

title: Update report
body: Define the time for the daily report update in the form hh:mm (for example 01:00). Daily report update is recommended to run at night so that report data is ready in the morning. If you are using a market data connector to fetch prices, adjust the time so that yesterday's prices are available through the connector when the nightly report data update begins.

title: Update report
body: Nightly report data updates are audited - system audit tracks when the system automatically fetches market prices through a market data connector and updates report data at night. Every time the system starts to fetch prices, the system audit contains a message “Nightly close price updates and report calculations started” and once prices have been fetched, the system audit contains a message “Nightly close price updates done, report calculations scheduled”. (Available from FA 3.10 onward)

title: Track data modifications
body: You can follow the changes made to contact, portfolio, transaction, trade order, security and market price data, posting rules or transaction type settings. Every time someone saves changes to one of these entities, a new version is saved in the system. The Versions window allows you to view these versions, allowing you to see who has changed what data and when.

title: Viewing individual versions
body: You can view the versions for each contact, portfolio, transaction, trade order, security, market price information, posting rule or transaction type setting from the Versions button in the corresponding window. The Versions window shows the newest 50 versions with the time of the version, the user who has made the changes and the type of the change.

title: Viewing individual versions
body: The versions are listed in the upper part of the window, and are divided into columns:

title: Viewing individual versions
body: Revision date

title: Viewing individual versions
body: The date and time of the version. Latest version is indicated with (Latest).

title: Viewing individual versions
body: User name

title: Viewing individual versions
body: The user name of the user who has made the change.

title: Viewing individual versions
body: Revision type

title: Viewing individual versions
body: The type of the change.

title: Viewing individual versions
body: Action

title: Viewing individual versions
body: The action that caused the version, more detailed description of how the change was initiated.

title: Viewing individual versions
body: You can view more details of the version by clicking a version from the list - the information saved with the version is shown in the lower part of the window.

title: Comparing versions
body: You can also compare versions with each other, by comparing a version to the latest version or choosing multiple versions from the list with the Ctrl button and comparing these against each other. The differences are highlighted when comparing revisions. You can compare revision with a right-click of you mouse, where you can find the following options:

title: Comparing versions
body: Compare with latest

title: Comparing versions
body: Compare the chosen version to the latest version.

title: Comparing versions
body: Compare with latest (only difference)

title: Comparing versions
body: Compare the chosen version to the latest version, showing only differences.

title: Comparing versions
body: Compare each other

title: Comparing versions
body: Compare the chosen versions with each other.

title: Comparing versions
body: Compare each other (only difference)

title: Comparing versions
body: Compare the chosen versions with each other, showing only differences.

title: Fund wizard
body: The Fund wizard lets you set up a fund or edit settings for an existing fund in FA Fund Management app. When you set up a fund in the FA Fund management app, FA creates a fund portfolio with the specified properties in FA Back to store the fund information and manage fund investments.

title: Fund wizard
body: To set up a new fund, click the Add fund button at the top-right of the NAV status view. To view and edit the settings of an existing fund, click the Edit fund button in the Fund details pane.

title: Fund wizard
body: The Fund wizard fields are described below.

title: Basic info tab
body: The Basic info tab contains the basic information about the fund.

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund company*

title: Basic info tab
body: The company the fund is administered by. See Fund company wizard.

title: Basic info tab
body: Language*

title: Basic info tab
body: The language to use in fund portfolio reports. You can also see the language of the fund in the contact of the company in FA Back.

title: Basic info tab
body: Juridical*

title: Basic info tab
body: Juridical form of the fund company. You can also see the juridical form in the contact of the company in FA Back.

title: Basic info tab
body: Name*

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund name.

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund business ID

title: Basic info tab
body: The ID provided by the authorities for your fund. Fund business ID is used for tax reporting purposes. The ID is saved in FA Back. You can find it in the Portfolio window, IDs tab.

title: Basic info tab
body: Inception date

title: Basic info tab
body: The date when the fund starts.

title: Basic info tab
body: ID*

title: Basic info tab
body: A unique fund ID used to identify the fund and search for funds. You should only use numbers and letters (a-z).

title: Basic info tab
body: Currency*

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund currency. Once you create a fund, the currency can't be changed.

title: Basic info tab
body: Valuation method*

title: Basic info tab
body: Valuation method for the fund portfolio:

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price with adjustments – Uses transaction types that control the market value of the positions with the transaction's trade amount, such as Private Equity transaction types.

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price with separate items – Valuates portfolio with average price, but keeps track of original purchase dates.

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO (combined) – Valuates the portfolio based directly on transactions in the subportfolios.

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO with adjustments – Uses transaction types that control the market value of the positions with the transaction's trade amount, such as Private Equity transaction types.

title: Basic info tab
body: Type*

title: Basic info tab
body: Portfolio type. Choose the type that corresponds to the fund portfolio.

title: Cash accounts
body: Cash accounts for the fund.

title: Cash accounts
body: Name*

title: Cash accounts
body: Account name.

title: Cash accounts
body: Currency*

title: Cash accounts
body: Account currency.

title: Cash accounts
body: Account number*

title: Cash accounts
body: The account number, for example, the bank account number.

title: Cash accounts
body: Set as default account

title: Cash accounts
body: Set the account as the default account of the portfolio. All transactions are by default created against this account.

title: Cash accounts
body: Shared to all parent portfolio's subportfolios

title: Cash accounts
body: Make the account available in the parent portfolio and in the other portfolios under the parent portfolio. Choose this option, for example, if you are going to use FX-hedged share classes in your fund. For details, see Manage funds with FX-hedged share classes.

title: Schedules tab
body: The Schedules tab contains schedule settings for calculating NAV, fees, and unofficial NAV for the fund. Schedules let you track your fund's status. For example, you can see if NAV or fees have to be calculated today. You need to fill in the dates only once. After that, dates are updated every time you accept the calculation.

title: Schedules tab
body: The Schedules tab features settings for different workflows. You can set a schedule to calculate:

title: Schedules tab
body: NAV and fees as a part of regular NAV calculation workflow.

title: Schedules tab
body: Fees, in addition to the regular NAV calculation schedule, between the regular NAV calculation dates (to set a schedule for this workflow, click Add separate fee calculation schedule).

title: Schedules tab
body: Performance fee with equalization method (to set a schedule for performance fee equalization, click Add fee crystallization schedule). You can also use the same schedule for fee capitalization if you have chosen it in fee settings on the Fee structure tab.

title: Schedules tab
body: Unofficial NAV for reporting purposes between the scheduled regular NAV calculations (to set a schedule for this workflow, click Add unofficial NAV calculation schedule).

title: Schedules tab
body: To learn more about calculation workflows, see Workflows and NAV statuses.

title: Schedules tab
body: Frequency

title: Schedules tab
body: Calculation frequency: daily, weekly, every two weeks, and so on.

title: Schedules tab
body: If you want to make calculations without a preset schedule, choose "No schedule" and select Allow non-scheduled calculations below. This option is available for NAV, fees, and unofficial NAV calculations.

title: Schedules tab
body: Holiday calendar

title: Schedules tab
body: The holiday calendar to take into account in the calculation schedule. If you don't find a suitable holiday calendar from the list, you can create a calendar in FA Back (for details, see Preference - Securities in the FA Back reference).

title: Schedules tab
body: Roll convention

title: Schedules tab
body: Calculation schedule based on the day of the month or day of the week. One of the most common roll conventions is "EOM" (end-of-month).

title: Schedules tab
body: You set the calculation frequency to "Every three months" and the first calculation date is on June 30th. The calculation dates will fall on the 30th of each month (September 30th, December 30th, March 30th, and so on). For months with 31 days, the calculation date won't be the last day of the month. If you choose the "End of Month (EOM)" roll convention, the system will recognize that June 30th is the last day of the month, and the calculation dates will fall on the last day of each month (September 30th, December 31st, March 31st, and so on).

title: Schedules tab
body: Business day convention

title: Schedules tab
body: Business day convention determines how to adjust a date if it falls on a non-business day.

title: Schedules tab
body: First date

title: Schedules tab
body: The date for which the calculation is made for the first time.

title: Schedules tab
body: Previous date

title: Schedules tab
body: The date for which the latest NAV or fees were calculated. For the newly created fund, previous NAV date must be the same as the first NAV date.

title: Schedules tab
body: Calculation delay in days

title: Schedules tab
body: The number of days between the NAV or fees date and the calculation date. Enter "0" to calculate NAV or fees on the same date, or choose the number of days to calculate NAV or fees with a delay.

title: Schedules tab
body: Calculate next days

title: Schedules tab
body: The button sets the next NAV or fees date and calculation dates according to the information entered above.

title: Schedules tab
body: Next NAV date

title: Schedules tab
body: The next NAV or fees date based on the frequency, holiday calendar conventions and the first NAV or fees date chosen above.

title: Schedules tab
body: Previous calculation date

title: Schedules tab
body: Previous calculation date based on the previous NAV or fees date and calculation delay.

title: Schedules tab
body: Next calculation date

title: Schedules tab
body: Next calculation date based on the next NAV or fees date and calculation delay.

title: Schedules tab
body: Allow non-scheduled calculations

title: Schedules tab
body: Allows starting a calculation outside the schedule, when the fund has "No action" status. For example, this can be useful in case you don't calculate scheduled NAV often but there are big movements in fund’s capital that affect the valuation of the fund. The Allow non-scheduled calculations option is available for NAV, fees, and unofficial NAV calculations.

title: Schedules tab
body: Non-scheduled NAV calculation result is shown in the NAV window. The calculation date is shown in the Latest NAV column in the NAV status view.

title: Fee structure tab
body: The Fee structure tab lets you set or edit the fees applied to the whole fund. Fund-level fees are calculated first, in the order you place them in the Fund wizard, followed by the share class fees.

title: Fee structure tab
body: To add fees per share class, use the Share class wizard.

title: Fund fees
body: The Fund fees section lists the fund fees. To add a fee formula, click the Add fee button at the top-right.

title: Fund fees
body: Fee formula

title: Fund fees
body: Fee formula used to calculate the fee and generate fee transaction.

title: Fund fees
body: Fee transaction type

title: Fund fees
body: Transaction type linked to the chosen fee formula.

title: Fund fees
body: Amount or %

title: Fund fees
body: Fee percentage or amount in the fund currency, depending on the fee formula.

title: Fund fees
body: Decimals

title: Fund fees
body: The number of decimals used for calculating fees (0 to 10). The "Default" value is 2 decimals.

title: Fund fees
body: Ex-post cost category

title: Fund fees
body: Ex-post cost category for the fee. The categorization is used in cost analysis and reporting (see View ex-post costs and charges in FA User guide), as well as for creating kickbacks (see Rebate contracts (kickbacks) in FA User guide).

title: Fund fees
body: Additional options

title: Fund fees
body: Additional fee setups.

title: Fund fees
body: Calculate fee per security

title: Fund fees
body: Run the formula multiple times, for each security in the fund investment portfolio. Used, for example, for kickbacks.

title: Fund fees
body: Formula sets its own account

title: Fund fees
body: Create an account for the fee formula. For example, it can be useful with accrued account interest transactions over multiple accounts.

title: Fund fees
body: Include in income distribution

title: Fund fees
body: Include the fee in the income distribution calculation.

title: Fund fees
body: Use crystallization schedule for capitalization

title: Fund fees
body: Capitalize fees automatically on the crystallization date when you accept NAV. The crystallization dates are defined in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab. Fees are capitalized to the account that has the “Fee capitalization” tag. If no account is marked with this tag, fees are capitalized to the default cash account.

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: The Alternative fee calculation modes section contains advanced settings that affect fee handling in the NAV calculation. Leave the selections unticked for regular fee handling.

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: Include fees calculated since the previous NAV calculation date in the current NAV calculation (if fees are calculated separately from NAV)

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: Take the fees calculated since previous NAV calculation into account when calculating the current NAV.

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: Allocate fees per share class from the beginning of the fund (for example, for private equity funds)

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: Calculate fees per share class since the beginning of the fund (not since the latest NAV calculation). To learn more, see NAV calculation.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The Performance fee equalization section contains the fee formula to use if you calculate performance fee and equalize it regularly according to the crystallization schedule. In addition to choosing the fee formula here, you need to define the crystallization schedule in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab, and the fee parameters in the Share class wizard, Fee structure tab.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Select Calculate performance equalization fee with contingent redemption method and fill in the fields to define the fee settings:

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee formula

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee formula used to calculate performance fee transactions: choose "Performance fee with crystallization".

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee transaction type

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Transaction type linked to the chosen performance fee formula.

title: Fund reporting tab
body: The Fund reporting tab lets you define the settings to produce fund reporting data, including fund KPIs, and store it in the FA Fund Management app (see Fund reporting view for details). Click Enable fund reporting and fill in the fields.

title: Fund reporting tab
body: Reporting schedule

title: Fund reporting tab
body: The settings for the fund reporting schedule are similar to NAV and fee calculation schedules (see Schedules tab).

title: Fund reporting tab
body: Allocation groups

title: Fund reporting tab
body: Allocation groups to analyze the fund portfolio contents. To learn more about allocations, see ??? in the FA Back reference.

title: Order execution tab
body: The Order execution tab lets you define and edit the automatic trade order execution settings.

title: Order execution tab
body: Cut-off time

title: Order execution tab
body: The cut-off time for the fund in 24 h format, for example, “13:00”. After you set the cut-off time, use decision tables make sure that certain transactions or trade orders that come after the cut-off time don't affect the NAV calculation. To learn more, see Set up cut-off time in FA User guide.

title: Order execution tab
body: Enable automatic order execution

title: Order execution tab
body: Enable automatic order execution and create transactions for the fund when NAV is accepted.

title: Order execution tab
body: Default transaction types

title: Order execution tab
body: Transaction types for the cash transactions (unit holder deposits and withdrawals).

title: Order execution tab
body: Account for cash transactions

title: Order execution tab
body: Account number for the cash transactions. Leave the field empty to use the default account.

title: Order execution tab
body: Transaction types for bookkeeping

title: Order execution tab
body: For bookkeeping purposes, you can provide transaction types that are used when creating cash transaction for client orders whose settlement date doesn’t follow the default logic.

title: Order execution tab
body: Leave these transaction types empty to use the accounts for cash transactions instead.

title: Client orders
body: Settlement cycle

title: Client orders
body: Setting to define the settlement date for subscriptions and redemptions if it is missing in the client order. Enter the number of days after the transaction date.

title: Client orders
body: Account for client transactions

title: Client orders
body: Account used for client transactions created from trade orders.

title: Client orders
body: Use the account of the trade order to transactions

title: Client orders
body: Use the currency account (or default account) to transactions

title: Client orders
body: Use the default account to transactions

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Default transaction types

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Transaction types for the cash transactions (unit holder deposits and withdrawals). We recommend using the "Deposit - Fund (FMDEP)" and "Withdrawal - Fund (FMWD)" types.

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Account for cash transactions

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Account number for the cash transactions. Leave the field empty to use the default account.

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Transaction types for bookkeeping

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: For bookkeeping purposes, you can provide transaction types that are used when creating cash transaction for client orders whose settlement date doesn’t follow the default logic.

title: Cash transactions created for the fund
body: Leave these transaction types empty to use the accounts for cash transactions instead.

title: Breakdown of cash
body: Breakdown of trade amount in cash transactions.

title: Breakdown of cash
body: Par value (the first NAV value)

title: Breakdown of cash
body: Par value to use in the deposit and withdrawal transactions.

title: Breakdown of cash
body: Par value cost type

title: Breakdown of cash
body: Income distribution tax type

title: Breakdown of cash
body: Over/ under value cost type

title: Breakdown of cash
body: Swing tax type

title: Breakdown of cash
body: Cost and tax types to record in the deposit and withdrawal transactions.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: The NAV reporting tab features options for setting up custom NAV reports and sending NAV reports by email.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: NAV report PDF template

title: NAV reporting tab
body: The path to the PDF template used for building NAV reports. The path to the default template is pre-filled for you. To use a custom template, enter the template path in the field. To learn more about configuring custom reports, see Customize the NAV report (XLSX) in FA Developer guide.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: NAV report XLSX template

title: NAV reporting tab
body: The path to the XSLX template used for building NAV reports. The path to the default template is pre-filled for you. To use a custom template, enter the template path in the field. To learn more about configuring custom reports, see Customize the NAV report (XLSX) in FA Developer guide.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: Send report via email

title: NAV reporting tab
body: Enable sending NAV reports by email. You can send NAV reports by email from FA Back (for instructions, see Send documents via email). We recommend that your administrator schedules the report sending in Tools → Administer → Scheduled functions in FA Back. For example, you can have the emails sent out every afternoon on the days when you calculate NAV.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: Recipients

title: NAV reporting tab
body: Emails to send the reports to. Email addresses in this field are automatically added to the "Report via email" list of emails in FA Back, meaning that all other reports that are generated for the fund are sent to this email too.

title: Swing pricing tab
body: The Swing pricing tab lets you define settings for swing pricing. Click Apply swing pricing and fill in the fields.

title: Swing pricing tab
body: Official NAV

title: Swing pricing tab
body: A setting to choose how swing adjustment is used in your fund. Choose one of the options:

title: Swing pricing tab
body: Swung NAV - Swing adjustment is included in official NAV. The logic of handling swing adjustment is shown in the table.

title: Swing pricing tab
body: Unswung NAV – Swing adjustment is not included in official NAV. The logic of handling swing adjustment is shown in the table.

title: Swing factor
body: Swing factor is used for adjusting the unit price.

title: Swing factor
body: For swinging up

title: Swing factor
body: The percentage to adjust the unit price if the net inflow of the fund exceeds the threshold.

title: Swing factor
body: For swinging down

title: Swing factor
body: The percentage to adjust the unit price if the net outflow of the fund exceeds the threshold.

title: Thresholds
body: Swing thresholds are the net inflow or net outflow of the fund that triggers the adjustment to the NAV. You can set a threshold in fund currency or as a percentage of the fund's total net asset value on the NAV date.

title: Thresholds
body: For swinging up

title: Thresholds
body: Net inflow that triggers swinging up.

title: Thresholds
body: For swinging down

title: Thresholds
body: Net outflow that triggers swinging down.

title: Income distribution tab
body: The Income distribution tab features settings for keeping track of the fund's accrued income and calculating the tax on it if needed. FA Fund Management app calculates the accrued income based on the bookkeeping postings and records the result into your fund every time you calculate NAV. You can choose to calculate tax on the accrued income at the same time.

title: Income distribution tab
body: After NAV is calculated, the system creates transactions for accrued income and calculated tax. The calculation also allocates accrued income per share class in security market data (Security window, Market data tab in FA Back) while pricing the share classes with NAV.

title: Income distribution tab
body: Click Enable income distribution and fill in the fields.

title: Accrued income
body: Settings to calculate accrued income.

title: Accrued income
body: Accrued income formula

title: Accrued income
body: Fee formula to calculate accrued income. Accrued income is calculated every time you calculate NAV.

title: Accrued income
body: Fee formula can be specified either for the whole fund or for a share class (not for both). Make sure that you don’t have any fee formulas in the Share class wizard, Fee structure tab if you use fund-level rules and the other way round.

title: Accrued income
body: Transaction type

title: Accrued income
body: Type of the transaction generated by the accrued income formula.

title: Accrued income
body: Bookkeeping accounts used to calculate income distributions

title: Accrued income
body: Fields for bookkeeping accounts to track accrued income. When you calculate NAV, FA sums up the balances on the specified bookkeeping accounts on the NAV date. To enter multiple account numbers, separate them with a semicolon. To include only part of the account balance in the calculation, enter a percentage after the account number. For example, "123456=45,5" means that 45,5% of the 123456 account balance is used in the calculation.

title: Accrued income
body: Mark all “Ready” bookkeeping postings from start of the year to the NAV date as “Reported” when NAV is accepted

title: Accrued income
body: Change the status of bookkeeping postings produced by income distribution when the NAV is accepted. In most cases, you need to have this option selected.

title: Accrued tax
body: Settings to calculate tax on accrued income.

title: Accrued tax
body: Calculate tax of the accrued income distribution

title: Accrued tax
body: Option to record tax to be paid on the accrued income. Fill in the tax parameters below.

title: Accrued tax
body: Tax formula

title: Accrued tax
body: Fee formula used to calculate tax on accrued income.

title: Accrued tax
body: Transaction type

title: Accrued tax
body: Type of the transaction generated by the tax formula.

title: Accrued tax
body: Tax percentage

title: Accrued tax
body: Percentage of accrued income to be paid as tax.

title: Accounting tab
body: The Accounting tab lets you define accounts and rules for generating postings for income distribution (for other income distribution settings, see Income distribution tab .

title: Accounting tab
body: Automated deferral runs before NAV calculation

title: Accounting tab
body: Settings for deferral runs before NAV calculation. You need to run deferrals to generate postings for the income distribution calculation.

title: Accounting tab
body: Choose the deferral type to run and the previous deferral date. If the previous deferral date is empty, the starting date of the fund is used.

title: Accounting tab
body: Accounting rules for income distribution-related postings

title: Accounting tab
body: Accounting rules that are used to generate postings related to income distribution. These rules are specified in the system configuration made by FA consultants. Enter them in the Accounting rules for income distribution-related postings field to change posting status to “Reported” when you accept NAV.

title: Advanced settings tab
body: The Advanced settings tab contains miscellaneous settings for your fund.

title: Unit certificates
body: Setting for unit certificates. To learn more about unit certificates in the FA Fund management app, see the Unit certificate

title: Unit certificates
body: Report template (PDF)

title: Unit certificates
body: The path to the custom Unit certificate template. For example, "/UnitCertificateCustom/Unit certificate".

title: Unit certificates
body: Transaction types

title: Unit certificates
body: Transaction types for the unit certificate to show in the Shareholder registry view. If empty, only the UC type is shown.

title: Pricing of share class without shareholders
body: Define how the unit price for newly created share classes with no shareholders is set:

title: Pricing of share class without shareholders
body: Select the checkbox to use the previous price of the share class.

title: Pricing of share class without shareholders
body: Leave the checkbox empty to use the price from the share class with a higher priority.

title: Allocation
body: Select the checkbox and choose the allocation groups to update share class allocations based on fund portfolio contents when you accept NAV. Allocations are updated for the configured group(s), based on fund portfolio’s allocations on the NAV date.

title: Share class wizard
body: The Share class wizard lets you create, edit or delete a fund share class. When you create a share class in the Fund management app, FA creates a share class security with the specified properties in FA Back.

title: Share class wizard
body: To add a share class, click the button in the Fund details pane.

title: Share class wizard
body: To edit a share class, click the button in the Share class details pane.

title: Share class wizard
body: To delete a share class click Delete in the Share class wizard. You can delete a share class only if it doesn't have any transactions and isn't used in benchmarks.

title: Basic info tab
body: Share class details and NAV calculation settings.

title: Basic info tab
body: Code*

title: Basic info tab
body: A unique code defined for the share class. The code is used to identify the share class security and search for securities in the system. We recommend using numbers and letters (a-z) and avoiding special characters in the security code.

title: Basic info tab
body: ISIN

title: Basic info tab
body: The ISIN code of the share class security.

title: Basic info tab
body: Name*

title: Basic info tab
body: Name of the share class security.

title: Basic info tab
body: Type*

title: Basic info tab
body: Share class security type. Choose the type that is configured for funds in Preferences. If you have standard solution configuration, use Collective investment vehicles type.

title: Basic info tab
body: Holiday calendar*

title: Basic info tab
body: A holiday calendar that determines business days and holidays in the market to set a settlement date for subscriptions and redemptions. Holiday calendar options are configured in Preferences. You can also set the default holiday calendar used for new securities in Preferences.

title: Basic info tab
body: Share class priority

title: Basic info tab
body: The order in which share class NAVs are calculated if there are multiple share classes. The NAV for the share class with the highest priority is calculated first.

title: Basic info tab
body: Decimal count for transaction units

title: Basic info tab
body: Number of decimals used in the units field of the client transactions. If the field is empty, the number of decimals set for the security type is used.

title: Pricing tab
body: Unit price settings:

title: Pricing tab
body: Currency

title: Pricing tab
body: Share class currency – the currency share class units are quoted in.

title: Pricing tab
body: Initial price

title: Pricing tab
body: (Set for a new share class). Initial price of the share class unit. Initial unit price is used for the first NAV calculation. The price you enter is copied to the Market data info tab in the Security window in FA Back.

title: Pricing tab
body: Date of initial price

title: Pricing tab
body: (Set when you create a share class). The date for which the initial unit price is valid.

title: Pricing tab
body: Format

title: Pricing tab
body: Unit price multipliers to use in calculations. For more information about multipliers, see the description of the Basic info tab in the Security window. Choose one of the options:

title: Pricing tab
body: Show price as is – Show the share class unit price without any multipliers.

title: Pricing tab
body: In percentage – Use "100" in both Multiplier fields for the security.

title: Pricing tab
body: Add manually – Enter the multipliers in the fields below.

title: Pricing tab
body: Decimals for share class NAV

title: Pricing tab
body: The number of decimals used in the share class NAV. If the field is empty, NAV is stored with 10 decimals.

title: Pricing tab
body: Enable dividend payments

title: Pricing tab
body: Enable dividend payments for the share class. You can calculate and execute dividends in the Dividends view. For details, see Dividends view.

title: Fee structure tab
body: The Fee structure tab defines costs and fees applied on the share class level. Share class-level fees are calculated after the fund level fees, in the order you put them in the Share class wizard. Click Add fee and enter the information about the share class fees:

title: Fund fees
body: Fund fees

title: Fund fees
body: Fee formula

title: Fund fees
body: Fee formula used to calculate the fee and generate fee transaction.

title: Fund fees
body: Fee transaction type

title: Fund fees
body: Transaction type linked to the chosen fee formula.

title: Fund fees
body: Amount or %

title: Fund fees
body: Fee percentage or amount in the fund currency, depending on the fee formula.

title: Fund fees
body: Decimals

title: Fund fees
body: The number of decimals used for calculating fees (0 to 10). The “Default” value is 2 decimals.

title: Fund fees
body: Ex-post cost category

title: Fund fees
body: Ex-post cost category for the fee. The categorization is used in cost analysis and reporting (see View ex-post costs and charges in FA User guide), as well as for creating kickbacks (see Rebate contracts (kickbacks) in FA User guide).

title: Fund fees
body: Account currency

title: Fund fees
body: The currency of the share class fee accrual account. Choose if the fees should be accrued in the fund currency or in the share class currency. The field is shown only if the share class currency is different from the fund currency.

title: Fund fees
body: Additional options

title: Fund fees
body: Additional fee setups.

title: Fund fees
body: Formula sets its own account

title: Fund fees
body: Set an account for the fee formula. For example, this can be useful with accrued account interest transactions over multiple accounts.

title: Fund fees
body: Include in income distribution

title: Fund fees
body: Include the fee in the income distribution calculation.

title: Fund fees
body: Use crystallization schedule for capitalization

title: Fund fees
body: Capitalize fees automatically on the crystallization date when you accept NAV. The crystallization dates are defined in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab. Fees are capitalized to the account that has “Fee capitalization” tag. If no account is marked with this tag, fees are capitalized to the default cash account.

title: Transaction fees
body: The Transaction fees section contains parameters for subscription and redemption fees and charging them automatically when you calculate NAV. Enter the subscription and redemption fee parameters:

title: Transaction fees
body: Calculate fee for net trade amount-based subscriptions

title: Transaction fees
body: The amount from which the subscription fee is calculated in net trade amount-based trade orders: order trade amount or the sum invested in the fund.

title: Transaction fees
body: Define default transaction fees

title: Transaction fees
body: Settings for subscription and redemption fees calculated automatically and included in the transaction:

title: Transaction fees
body: Cost percentage

title: Transaction fees
body: Fee percentage to calculate the fee amount.

title: Transaction fees
body: To set the fee as a fixed amount per transaction, enter "0" as a cost percentage and then specify the fee amount in the Minimum field.

title: Transaction fees
body: Minimum

title: Transaction fees
body: The minimum fee amount to charge.

title: Transaction fees
body: Currency

title: Transaction fees
body: Fee currency automatically set to the share class currency.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The Performance fee equalization section contains parameters to calculate and equalize performance fee. In addition to choosing the fee parameters here, you need to define the crystallization schedule in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab, and the fee formula in the Fund wizard, Fee structure tab.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee percentage

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee percentage to calculate the fee amount.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Hurdle rate

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The minimum NAV increase above HWM starting from which the performance fee is paid.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Day count

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Day count convention to use in performance fee calculation with hurdle rate. If the calculation period is less than a year, the hurdle rate is adjusted proportionally using the day count convention you chose.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: High-water mark

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The initial high water mark (HWM) to use for the performance fee calculation. Usually, HWM is set to the highest NAV value in the share class. On the crystallization date, FA Fund Management compares the share class NAV to the HWM. If NAV is higher than HWM, the HWM value is updated to the current NAV value.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: High-water mark date

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The date on which high-water mark is set.

title: Cash transactions tab
body: Account settings to handle deposits and withdrawals.

title: Cash transactions tab
body: Account number

title: Cash transactions tab
body: A fund portfolio account to record deposits and withdrawals to. If the field is empty, the account in the fund settings or the default account is used.

title: Tax reporting tab
body: Settings for the Finnish tax reporting: fund company business ID and fund business ID.

title: FX hedging tab
body: FX hedging settings to apply if your share class currency is different from the fund currency and you want to use FX hedging to neutralize the effect of the exchange rate. Click Enable FX hedging and fill in the fields. For full instruction on how to set up and manage FX-hedged share classes, see Manage funds with FX-hedged share classes in FA User guide.

title: FX hedging tab
body: Formula

title: FX hedging tab
body: The formula for the FX hedge accrual. You can choose the "FX hedge formula" that comes pre-configured in Standard solution.

title: FX hedging tab
body: FX hedge transaction type

title: FX hedging tab
body: Transaction type linked to the FX hedging formula.

title: FX hedging tab
body: Hedge parent portfolio

title: FX hedging tab
body: ID and portfolio type of the hedge parent portfolio that links fund and hedge portfolios in FA Back. The hedge parent portfolio is empty. It is used to group the fund and hedge portfolios and share accounts between them. You can edit the hedge parent portfolio properties only when you enable hedging for one of the fund share classes for the first time. After that, hedge parent portfolio is set and can't be edited.

title: FX hedging tab
body: Hedge portfolio

title: FX hedging tab
body: ID and portfolio type of the hedge portfolio that contains FX contracts in FA Back. You can edit the hedge portfolio properties only when you enable hedging for a share class. After that, the hedge portfolio is set and can't be edited.

title: Shareholder registry view
body: Shareholder registry view shows the fund’s shareholders and their ownership in the fund as a tree structure. Expand the shareholder name to view share classes to which the shareholder has ownership. Expand a share class to view the purchase lots in this share class.

title: Fund selection
body: The Select a fund dropdown at the top lets you choose a fund to view shareholders for. This dropdown shows the funds included in groups with a code starting with “FAFUND”. Learn more about setting up fund groups in FA User Guide.

title: Registry date
body: Choose the date in the Registry date field to view the fund shareholders for a specific date.

title: Load purchase lots
body: To see the purchase lots for each shareholder in the list, check the Load purchase lots box. This shows the whole history of purchase lots, including the ones not held anymore. By default, this option is disabled.

title: Table columns
body: Contact ID

title: Table columns
body: The customer’s contact ID stored in FA Back. This is a unique ID of the shareholder, such as a social security number.

title: Table columns
body: Shareholder

title: Table columns
body: The top level shows name of the shareholder. Lower levels show share classes the shareholder owns and date of the open purchase lots within each share class (the individual purchases the shareholder made into the share class). Purchase lots under each share class are ordered from oldest to newest according to FIFO (based on purchase lot date or the order they appear in during the same date).

title: Table columns
body: Address (Address 1, Address 2, Postal code, City, Country)

title: Table columns
body: The details stored in the Address info tab of the contact in FA Back. If the customer information contains multiple addresses, the shareholder registry shows the first address defined in the contact in FA Back.

title: Table columns
body: Tax country

title: Table columns
body: Classifications stored under "tax country" in the contact in FA Back. The tax country often indicates where the shareholder pays taxes. In the FA Platform, this is also used to calculate taxes.

title: Table columns
body: Share class

title: Table columns
body: The name of the share class.

title: Table columns
body: Total ownership

title: Table columns
body: Shown on the shareholder level. The shareholder’s ownership in the fund as a percentage of as a percentage of the net asset value of the fund:
